head.title: Migrating Monarch Butterflies Exceed Expected Numbers

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Migrating Monarch Butterflies Exceed Expected Numbers

abstract.p: New Jersey Audubon Society's Monarch Monitoring Project reports record numbers of monarch butterflies migrating through Cape May enroute to Mexico; photo (M)

block.p: Monarch butterflies, which stop in Cape May in September and October on their migration south to the mountains outside Mexico City, have been appearing in southern New Jersey in record numbers this year, said Louise Zemaitis, acting director of the Monarch Monitoring Project of the New Jersey Audobon Society.

The Monarch Monitoring Project has been counting monarch butterflies for nine years and had thought the count would be low this year because of the summer drought. Instead counters found that on Oct. 2, up to 250,000 monarchs moved through Cape May County.

Monarch butterflies, which stop in Cape May in September and October on their migration south to the mountains outside Mexico City, have been appearing in southern New Jersey in record numbers this year, said Louise Zemaitis, acting director of the Monarch Monitoring Project of the New Jersey Audobon Society.

The Monarch Monitoring Project has been counting monarch butterflies for nine years and had thought the count would be low this year because of the summer drought. Instead counters found that on Oct. 2, up to 250,000 monarchs moved through Cape May County.
''Even on an average day it should be a small fraction of that, and we had four other days with large numbers,'' Ms. Zemaitis said.
Monarchs feed on milkweed plants which absorb acid rain, therefore their numbers can indicate how healthy the environment is, Ms. Zemaitis said.
